title: Were the demands of record companies in the 1970s that signed acts put out 2-3 albums a year a money grab or a legitimate way to prod otherwise lazy artists? - Quora

response.answer_text: Krystka, I don’t believe it was either of those scenarios. There was big demand for product back in those days believe it or not and you’d have to remember that music had finally evolved and being produced with what was then allot of new technology and advances from the 50’s and 60’s. As an example, multi-track recording, better microphones, better distribution networks, guitars, keyboards and God let’s not forget the Moog. Artist where excited and label’s couldn't get enough of the public’s appetite. But with the advances in technology over the next 15 or 20 years cost begin to sky rocket. Better recording qualities, releasing in several formats, producer fee’s and artist demands for better pay and participation, which was only fair. There where also allot of original instrumentation used in the late 70’s and 80’s, like strings, horn players, etc. Label’s needed a way to cut cost, but yet they also knew that they had to keep their most successful artist happy. As an artist we tend to forget when we enter the main stream, like it or not it’s business. And as someone who has run an independent label I can assure you that I’ve had to lay the art aside when pinching the pennies to buy promotional materials, instruments, build out studio’s, etc. More back to your question, no it wasn’t as much a money grab as the excitement around an evolving industry that has gotten us to where we are today. Where there money grabbers, absolutely. Where there and are there lazy artist out there that got lucky, absolutely. There’s greed in allot of industries and the music industry is no exception. What set’s us apart is our own integrity and character and while not perfect do your damn best to keep good product coming. Darrell

We spent one year writing and recording one record album and had another 6–8 songs for a second album we started. Granted we all had jobs, but bands also spend 75% of their time on the road performing so I would consider a touring band only able to write perhaps 1–2 albums a year when they are busy touring and promoting and album. Also, it is far better to write music and record it live a few times as you will hear that you accidentaly played some cool parts and now the final version of the song can have a combination of the best ideas from perhaps four to six recordings. It is always better to record each song days later so you will get new and more ideas. Those bands that tried to push the envelope likely ended up with nice sounding music that never received much popularity, radio airplay or sold all that many copies. A band about to hit the big time needs to have perhaps 30–40 songs such that if they suceed they can quickly get music into the pipeline and this is what the Beatles did in the early years.
